Front:
Your organization needs to monitor application performance across multiple Azure regions and correlate telemetry with user sessions. The solution must provide automatic dependency mapping and detect anomalies.

A) Azure Monitor Logs with custom queries
B) Application Insights with distributed tracing
C) Azure Log Analytics workspace with agents
Back: B) Application Insights with distributed tracing
Extra: Application Insights is specifically designed for APM (Application Performance Management) with built-in distributed tracing, dependency mapping, and smart detection. Azure Monitor Logs is generic logging, while Log Analytics is the query engine - neither provides automatic application-specific insights.

Front:
A company requires centralized log collection from 500+ VMs across Azure, on-premises, and AWS. Logs must be queryable with KQL and retained for 3 years for compliance.

A) Azure Monitor Logs with Log Analytics workspace
B) Azure Storage account with lifecycle management
C) Azure Event Hubs with Stream Analytics
Back: A) Azure Monitor Logs with Log Analytics workspace
Extra: Log Analytics workspace is purpose-built for centralized log aggregation with KQL queries, supports hybrid/multi-cloud via agents, and offers configurable retention up to 730 days (with Archive for longer). Event Hubs is for streaming, Storage is for raw data without query capability.

Front:
You need to route platform logs from 200 Azure resources to three destinations: a SIEM tool, a storage account for archival, and Log Analytics for analysis.

A) Create diagnostic settings on each resource with multiple destinations
B) Use Event Grid to route Azure Monitor events
C) Stream to Event Hubs, then fan out to destinations
Back: A) Create diagnostic settings on each resource with multiple destinations
Extra: Diagnostic settings natively support multiple destinations (Storage, Log Analytics, Event Hubs) per resource. This is the recommended pattern. Event Grid doesn't handle platform logs. Event Hubs adds unnecessary complexity when diagnostic settings handle it directly.

Front:
An application must authenticate to Azure SQL Database without storing credentials. The app runs on Azure App Service. Security requires the solution minimize credential proliferation.

A) Store connection string with password in Azure Key Vault
B) Use App Service managed identity with SQL Azure AD authentication
C) Create a service principal and store credentials in App Configuration
Back: B) Use App Service managed identity with SQL Azure AD authentication
Extra: Managed Identity eliminates credential storage entirely - the app's identity is managed by Azure. SQL supports Azure AD authentication with managed identities. Option A still has credentials (in Key Vault). Option C proliferates service principals and still requires credential management.

Front:
Your organization has 10,000 employees who need conditional access to Azure resources based on device compliance, location, and risk signals. The solution must support step-up authentication for sensitive resources.

A) Azure AD B2C with custom policies
B) Azure AD Conditional Access with risk-based policies
C) Azure AD B2B with external identities
Back: B) Azure AD Conditional Access with risk-based policies
Extra: Conditional Access is designed for organizational policy enforcement with device state, location, risk signals, and MFA step-up. B2C is for customer-facing apps. B2B is for partner collaboration. Only Conditional Access provides comprehensive enterprise policy controls.

Front:
A multi-tenant SaaS application needs to provide identity management for customer organizations, allowing them to use their own identity providers via SAML/OIDC federation.

A) Azure AD B2B with guest invitations
B) Azure AD B2C with custom identity providers
C) Azure AD with home realm discovery
Back: B) Azure AD B2C with custom identity providers
Extra: B2C is purpose-built for customer identity with multi-tenancy and custom IDP federation (SAML, OIDC). B2B is for business partner collaboration. Standard Azure AD home realm discovery doesn't provide the multi-tenant customer isolation B2C offers.

Front:
An application running on-premises needs to access Azure Key Vault secrets. The solution must avoid storing credentials and work with the existing on-premises infrastructure.

A) Store service principal credentials locally and authenticate
B) Use Azure Arc and managed identity for on-premises servers
C) Implement certificate-based authentication with automated rotation
Back: B) Use Azure Arc and managed identity for on-premises servers
Extra: Azure Arc extends Azure management to on-premises resources, enabling managed identity for non-Azure VMs. This eliminates credential storage. Option A defeats the purpose. Option C still requires certificate management instead of leveraging built-in managed identity.

Front:
You need to authorize a user to manage Azure VM sizes and start/stop operations across 50 subscriptions, but not create or delete VMs. The solution must follow least privilege.

A) Assign Virtual Machine Contributor role at management group scope
B) Create a custom role with specific VM actions, assign at management group
C) Assign Contributor role at resource group scope for each VM group
Back: B) Create a custom role with specific VM actions, assign at management group
Extra: Custom role allows precise permission scoping (deallocate, start, resize) without broader create/delete permissions. Management group scope applies inheritance to all subscriptions. VM Contributor includes create/delete. Option C doesn't scale and may still grant too much access.

Front:
A development team needs temporary elevated access to production resources for incident response, with access automatically revoked after 4 hours and requiring approval.

A) Azure AD Privileged Identity Management (PIM) with time-bound assignments
B) Create a separate Azure AD group with Conditional Access time restrictions
C) Use Azure Automation to grant and revoke RBAC assignments on schedule
Back: A) Azure AD Privileged Identity Management (PIM) with time-bound assignments
Extra: PIM is purpose-built for just-in-time privileged access with approval workflows, time limits, and automatic revocation. Option B can't enforce automatic revocation. Option C is custom automation that duplicates PIM functionality without governance features.

Front:
Applications in your environment need access to database passwords, API keys, and TLS certificates. The solution must support automatic rotation and versioning with minimal application changes.

A) Azure App Configuration with Key Vault references
B) Azure Key Vault with managed identities
C) Azure Storage encrypted with customer-managed keys
Back: B) Azure Key Vault with managed identities
Extra: Key Vault is purpose-built for secrets, certificates, and keys with versioning and rotation support. Applications use managed identity to access. App Configuration is for app settings not secrets. CMK Storage encryption addresses data-at-rest encryption, not secret management.

Front:
Your organization has 200 subscriptions across 5 business units. You need to enforce tagging standards, with cost center and environment tags required on all resources.

A) Create Azure Policy at management group scope with Deny effect
B) Use resource locks at subscription level
C) Implement Azure Blueprints with policy assignments
Back: A) Create Azure Policy at management group scope with Deny effect
Extra: Azure Policy with Deny effect prevents resource creation without required tags. Management group scope applies to all child subscriptions. Resource locks prevent deletion/modification, not tag validation. Blueprints are for initial environment setup, not ongoing enforcement.

Front:
You need to organize 50 subscriptions for a company with 3 divisions (each with dev, test, prod environments). The structure must support division-level billing, centralized policy, and delegated administration.

A) Management groups: Root → Division → Environment → Subscriptions
B) Management groups: Root → Environment → Division → Subscriptions
C) Single management group with RBAC at subscription level
Back: A) Management groups: Root → Division → Environment → Subscriptions
Extra: Hierarchy aligns with organizational structure: divisions for billing/administration, then environments for RBAC/policy. This allows division-level cost analysis and delegation while applying environment policies (e.g., prod restrictions). Option B inverts the model. Option C lacks structure for policy inheritance.

Front:
Your company requires all Azure resources to be tagged with owner, cost-center, and environment. Existing resources lack tags. You need to enforce tagging and remediate non-compliant resources.

A) Azure Policy with Append effect and remediation task
B) Azure Automation runbook to scan and tag resources
C) Azure Resource Graph query with PowerShell tagging script
Back: A) Azure Policy with Append effect and remediation task
Extra: Azure Policy Append effect automatically adds missing tags. Remediation tasks fix existing non-compliant resources. This provides ongoing enforcement. Options B and C are one-time fixes without ongoing compliance enforcement. Policy is the native governance tool for this scenario.

Front:
A company needs to grant external auditors read-only access to all Azure resources for 30 days, with access automatically expiring. The solution must provide audit logs of auditor activities.

A) Azure AD B2B with PIM time-bound Reader role assignment
B) Create shared credentials with Azure AD Conditional Access
C) Guest accounts with permanent Reader role and manual removal
Back: A) Azure AD B2B with PIM time-bound Reader role assignment
Extra: B2B brings external users into Azure AD. PIM provides time-bound access with automatic expiration. All activities are logged in Azure AD and Activity logs. Option B violates security practices. Option C requires manual management and lacks automatic expiration.

Front:
Your organization must ensure that no Azure SQL Database can be created without Transparent Data Encryption and geo-replication enabled across all subscriptions.

A) Azure Policy with DeployIfNotExists effect
B) ARM templates with required parameters
C) Azure Blueprints with resource definitions
Back: A) Azure Policy with DeployIfNotExists effect
Extra: DeployIfNotExists policy automatically configures TDE and geo-replication if not present. Applies continuously to all resources. ARM templates only affect new deployments via that template. Blueprints are for initial setup, not ongoing enforcement of existing resources.

Front:
A development team manages their own Azure AD app registrations. You need to ensure that only apps with certificate credentials (not client secrets) can be created, preventing password-based authentication.

A) Azure Policy for app registration validation
B) Azure AD Conditional Access with authentication requirements
C) Custom RBAC role limiting app registration permissions
Back: A) Azure Policy for app registration validation
Extra: Azure Policy can validate app registration properties including credential types. This enforces the rule at creation time. Conditional Access applies to user sign-in, not app registration creation. RBAC controls who can create apps, not the properties of apps created.

Front:
You need to provide developers with temporary credentials to access Azure resources during development, with credentials automatically expiring after 8 hours and no manual revocation required.

A) Service principal with client secret rotation
B) Managed identity assigned to developer workstations
C) Azure AD PIM with time-bound role assignment
Back: C) Azure AD PIM with time-bound role assignment
Extra: PIM provides just-in-time access with automatic expiration. Developers activate roles when needed. Service principals don't expire automatically without custom logic. Managed identities are for resources not user accounts. PIM is designed exactly for this temporary access scenario.

Front:
Your company requires that all production resource groups are protected from accidental deletion. Authorized administrators must still be able to delete resources within the groups.

A) Apply ReadOnly lock at resource group scope
B) Apply CanNotDelete lock at resource group scope
C) Use Azure Policy with Deny delete operations
Back: B) Apply CanNotDelete lock at resource group scope
Extra: CanNotDelete lock prevents group deletion while allowing resource operations inside. ReadOnly prevents all modifications. Policy Deny can be bypassed by policy exemptions and doesn't provide the same system-level protection as locks. CanNotDelete is the precise solution for this requirement.

Front:
A web application stores user profile data with the following requirements: 10ms read latency, 100ms write latency tolerance, data accessed by user ID, and 99.99% availability.

A) Azure Cosmos DB with Session consistency
B) Azure SQL Database with geo-replication
C) Azure Table Storage with RA-GRS
Back: A) Azure Cosmos DB with Session consistency
Extra: Cosmos DB provides single-digit ms latency, 99.99% availability SLA, and Session consistency balances performance with read-your-writes guarantee. SQL Database has higher latency. Table Storage is cheaper but higher latency and less consistency control. Cosmos DB excels at low-latency key-value access.

Front:
Your application needs to store 500TB of archival data accessed once per year for compliance audits. The solution must minimize costs while ensuring data is available within 24 hours when needed.

A) Azure Blob Storage Archive tier with lifecycle management
B) Azure Blob Storage Cool tier with GRS replication
C) Azure Data Lake Storage Gen2 with Hot tier
Back: A) Azure Blob Storage Archive tier with lifecycle management
Extra: Archive tier has the lowest storage cost for rarely accessed data. Rehydration takes up to 15 hours (within 24h requirement). Lifecycle management automates tier transitions. Cool tier is more expensive for infrequent access. Hot tier is significantly more expensive for archival scenarios.

Front:
A financial application requires ACID transactions across multiple table entities with strong consistency guarantees. Data volume is 50GB with complex relational queries needed.

A) Azure Cosmos DB with Strong consistency
B) Azure SQL Database with Business Critical tier
C) Azure Table Storage with entity group transactions
Back: B) Azure SQL Database with Business Critical tier
Extra: SQL Database provides full ACID transactions, strong consistency, and complex relational query support (JOINs, stored procedures). Cosmos DB is eventually consistent by design (even Strong consistency has nuances). Table Storage has limited transaction scope (entity groups only) and no complex queries.

Front:
Your e-commerce application needs a globally distributed database with multi-region writes, automatic failover, and <10ms read latency for users worldwide. Data conflicts must be handled automatically.

A) Azure SQL Database with active geo-replication
B) Azure Cosmos DB with multi-region writes
C) Azure Database for PostgreSQL with read replicas
Back: B) Azure Cosmos DB with multi-region writes
Extra: Cosmos DB is purpose-built for global distribution with multi-region writes, automatic conflict resolution, and single-digit ms latency. SQL geo-replication requires manual failover for writes. PostgreSQL read replicas don't support multi-region writes. Cosmos DB is the only true multi-master solution.

Front:
A data warehouse workload requires complex analytical queries across 10TB of structured data with automatic indexing and query optimization. The solution must support T-SQL.

A) Azure Synapse Analytics dedicated SQL pool
B) Azure SQL Database Hyperscale tier
C) Azure Cosmos DB with SQL API
Back: A) Azure Synapse Analytics dedicated SQL pool
Extra: Synapse dedicated SQL pool is optimized for data warehousing with MPP architecture, columnstore indexes, and T-SQL support. Hyperscale is for large OLTP databases, not analytics. Cosmos DB SQL API is for NoSQL documents, not relational analytics with complex joins.

Front:
An IoT solution ingests 10,000 events per second that must be processed in order per device, with exactly-once delivery semantics and 7-day message retention.

A) Azure Event Hubs with partitioning by device ID
B) Azure Service Bus with session-enabled queues
C) Azure Event Grid with retry policy
Back: B) Azure Service Bus with session-enabled queues
Extra: Service Bus sessions guarantee FIFO ordering per session (device), exactly-once delivery, and configurable retention. Event Hubs doesn't guarantee exactly-once without consumer logic. Event Grid is for reactive events, not high-throughput ordered message processing with retention.

Front:
You need to migrate 100TB of on-premises data files to Azure Blob Storage with minimal bandwidth usage over a 2-week window. Internet connection is 100Mbps.

A) Use Azure Data Box for offline transfer
B) Use AzCopy with bandwidth throttling
C) Implement Azure File Sync
Back: A) Use Azure Data Box for offline transfer
Extra: 100TB / 100Mbps = ~92 days of continuous transfer. Data Box ships physical disks, bypassing network. AzCopy would exceed the timeline. File Sync is for file share scenarios, not bulk migration. Data Box is designed for large offline migrations when bandwidth is constrained.

Front:
A reporting application queries data from Azure SQL Database, Cosmos DB, and Blob Storage. Queries must aggregate data across sources without ETL pipelines. The solution must support SQL-like queries.

A) Azure Synapse Analytics with PolyBase and Spark
B) Azure Data Factory with mapping data flows
C) Azure Databricks with Delta Lake
Back: A) Azure Synapse Analytics with PolyBase and Spark
Extra: Synapse integrates SQL and Spark, queries external data via PolyBase without movement, and provides unified SQL interface. Data Factory is for ETL, not ad-hoc queries. Databricks requires data movement. Synapse serverless SQL pool can query data in-place across sources.

Front:
Your application stores user documents that average 2MB each. Access patterns: 80% of reads are from documents created in the last 30 days. Total storage grows at 10TB/month. Minimize costs while maintaining <100ms read latency for recent documents.

A) Azure Blob Storage with Hot tier and lifecycle policy to Cool after 30 days
B) Azure Blob Storage Cool tier with CDN caching
C) Azure Files Premium with snapshots
Back: A) Azure Blob Storage with Hot tier and lifecycle policy to Cool after 30 days
Extra: Hot tier provides low latency for frequently accessed data. Lifecycle management automatically transitions to Cool tier after 30 days, reducing costs on older data. Option B puts all data in Cool (higher latency/costs for frequent access). Premium Files is expensive for this use case.

Front:
A database must support complex JSON document queries with secondary indexes, ACID transactions, and PostgreSQL compatibility for existing application code. Data size is 500GB.

A) Azure Cosmos DB for PostgreSQL
B) Azure Database for PostgreSQL with JSONB columns
C) Azure SQL Database with JSON functions
Back: B) Azure Database for PostgreSQL with JSONB columns
Extra: PostgreSQL JSONB provides native JSON support with indexing, full ACID transactions, and maintains PostgreSQL compatibility. Cosmos DB for PostgreSQL is for distributed scenarios (not needed here). SQL Database JSON functions are less mature than PostgreSQL JSONB for complex queries.

Front:
Your company needs a database for a new OLTP application with 10,000 transactions/second, 99.99% uptime, and automatic index tuning. Total database size: 4TB with 10% monthly growth.

A) Azure SQL Database Hyperscale with auto-tuning enabled
B) Azure SQL Managed Instance with Business Critical tier
C) Azure Cosmos DB with Strong consistency
Back: A) Azure SQL Database Hyperscale with auto-tuning enabled
Extra: Hyperscale supports 100TB, auto-tuning for index recommendations, and 99.99% SLA. Optimized for OLTP scale. Managed Instance is for SQL Server migrations with instance features. Cosmos DB is for NoSQL scenarios. Hyperscale's read scale-out and snapshot backups excel at large OLTP workloads.

Front:
An analytics solution processes daily batch jobs querying 50TB of historical data stored as Parquet files. Queries are ad-hoc and infrequent (10 queries/day). Minimize costs.

A) Azure Synapse serverless SQL pool querying Data Lake
B) Azure Synapse dedicated SQL pool with daily pause/resume
C) Azure Databricks cluster with auto-termination
Back: A) Azure Synapse serverless SQL pool querying Data Lake
Extra: Serverless SQL pool charges per query (per TB scanned), no cost when idle. Perfect for infrequent queries. Dedicated pool charges for provisioned resources even paused (storage costs remain). Databricks has cluster startup overhead and higher cost per query for infrequent workloads.

Front:
A time-series IoT application stores sensor readings accessed by time range and device ID. Expected: 1 million writes/sec, 100GB/day data growth, with automatic data expiration after 90 days.

A) Azure Cosmos DB with Time-to-Live (TTL) and partition key on device ID
B) Azure SQL Database with temporal tables and partitioning
C) Azure Time Series Insights Gen2
Back: A) Azure Cosmos DB with Time-to-Live (TTL) and partition key on device ID
Extra: Cosmos DB scales horizontally for 1M writes/sec, TTL automatically expires old data, partition key (device+time) ensures efficient queries. SQL Database can't scale to this write throughput. TSI Gen2 is in sunset phase, not recommended for new deployments. Cosmos DB is the modern time-series solution.

Front:
Your database must support full-text search across 10 million product descriptions with filters on price, category, and ratings. Search latency must be <50ms.

A) Azure Cognitive Search indexing Cosmos DB data
B) Azure SQL Database full-text indexes
C) Azure Cosmos DB with composite indexes
Back: A) Azure Cognitive Search indexing Cosmos DB data
Extra: Cognitive Search is purpose-built for full-text and faceted search with <50ms latency, integrates with Cosmos DB for source data. SQL full-text search is less performant at scale. Cosmos DB composite indexes support filtering but not full-text search. Cognitive Search provides relevance ranking and facets.

Front:
A gaming leaderboard application requires sub-millisecond read/write latency for player scores with automatic ranking. Expected: 50,000 concurrent users updating scores.

A) Azure Cache for Redis with sorted sets
B) Azure Cosmos DB with composite indexes
C) Azure SQL Database with in-memory OLTP
Back: A) Azure Cache for Redis with sorted sets
Extra: Redis sorted sets provide sub-millisecond operations for leaderboards with automatic ranking by score. Perfect for this use case. Cosmos DB has single-digit ms (not sub-ms). SQL in-memory OLTP doesn't match Redis performance for this pattern. Redis is purpose-built for leaderboard scenarios.

Front:
Your application needs to store encryption keys used for customer data encryption. Keys must be hardware-backed, support key rotation, and maintain an audit log of all key usage.

A) Azure Key Vault Premium SKU with HSM-backed keys
B) Azure Key Vault Standard SKU with software keys
C) Azure Dedicated HSM
Back: A) Azure Key Vault Premium SKU with HSM-backed keys
Extra: Key Vault Premium provides HSM-backed keys (FIPS 140-2 Level 2), versioning for rotation, and audit logging. Standard SKU uses software keys only. Dedicated HSM is for highly regulated industries requiring Level 3 compliance, overkill for typical customer data. Premium KV balances security and manageability.

Front:
A hybrid application stores data in on-premises SQL Server and Azure SQL Database. Reporting queries must access both sources without data replication. Queries use T-SQL with JOINs across sources.

A) Azure Synapse Analytics with external tables via PolyBase
B) Azure Data Factory with copy activity to staging
C) SQL Server linked servers to Azure SQL Database
Back: A) Azure Synapse Analytics with external tables via PolyBase
Extra: Synapse PolyBase creates external tables for both on-premises (via Managed VNet or ExpressRoute) and Azure SQL, enabling T-SQL JOINs without replication. Linked servers don't scale and have security issues. Data Factory requires ETL/replication. Synapse provides unified query layer.

Front:
Your organization stores 1PB of compliance data that must be retained for 10 years with WORM (write-once, read-many) guarantees. Data is accessed once during audits (expected 2 times over 10 years).

A) Azure Blob Storage with immutability policies and Archive tier
B) Azure Data Lake Storage Gen2 with access control
C) Azure Files with snapshots
Back: A) Azure Blob Storage with immutability policies and Archive tier
Extra: Immutability policies provide WORM compliance. Archive tier minimizes cost for rare access. Data Lake adds complexity without necessary features. Azure Files is for SMB shares, not compliance archival. Blob immutability policies meet legal/regulatory requirements for tamper-proof storage.

Front:
A machine learning pipeline processes 10TB datasets stored in Azure. The pipeline runs weekly and requires POSIX filesystem semantics with hierarchical namespace for data organization.

A) Azure Data Lake Storage Gen2 with hierarchical namespace
B) Azure Blob Storage with flat namespace
C) Azure Files Premium with NFS protocol
Back: A) Azure Data Lake Storage Gen2 with hierarchical namespace
Extra: ADLS Gen2 provides hierarchical namespace (folders with POSIX semantics), optimized for analytics, supports Hadoop/Spark. Blob flat namespace doesn't provide directory operations. Azure Files NFS works but lacks analytics optimizations. ADLS Gen2 is purpose-built for big data analytics pipelines.

Front:
An application must replicate data across Azure regions with automatic failover and require that writes are committed to at least 2 regions before acknowledging success to the application.

A) Azure Storage with GZRS replication
B) Azure Cosmos DB with Strong consistency and multi-region
C) Azure SQL Database with auto-failover groups
Back: B) Azure Cosmos DB with Strong consistency and multi-region
Extra: Cosmos DB Strong consistency with multi-region writes ensures synchronous replication to multiple regions before write acknowledgment. GZRS is asynchronous. SQL auto-failover groups have a single write region with async replication. Only Cosmos DB Strong consistency provides synchronous multi-region write commits.

Front:
Your web application requires session state storage for 100,000 concurrent users with <5ms read/write latency and automatic expiration of inactive sessions after 30 minutes.

A) Azure Cache for Redis with sliding expiration
B) Azure Cosmos DB with TTL
C) Azure Table Storage with SAS tokens
Back: A) Azure Cache for Redis with sliding expiration
Extra: Redis provides sub-5ms latency, native session state support, and sliding expiration (resets on access). Cosmos DB has higher latency (single-digit ms). Table Storage has much higher latency and doesn't support automatic expiration. Redis is purpose-built for session state with ASP.NET/Java integration.

Front:
A financial reporting application requires read-after-write consistency within a single region, accepts eventual consistency for global reads, and must minimize latency for local users while supporting global distribution.

A) Azure Cosmos DB with Session consistency
B) Azure Cosmos DB with Eventual consistency
C) Azure Cosmos DB with Strong consistency
Back: A) Azure Cosmos DB with Session consistency
Extra: Session consistency guarantees read-your-writes within a session (single region), provides monotonic reads, and has lower latency than Strong. Eventual doesn't guarantee read-your-writes. Strong adds unnecessary latency for global reads. Session balances consistency with performance for this scenario.

Front:
Your application needs to query JSON documents stored in Azure Blob Storage (10TB) using SQL syntax without moving data. Queries are ad-hoc and infrequent.

A) Azure Synapse serverless SQL pool with OPENROWSET
B) Azure Data Factory with copy activity to SQL Database
C) Azure Databricks with mount points
Back: A) Azure Synapse serverless SQL pool with OPENROWSET
Extra: Synapse serverless SQL can query JSON in Blob Storage via OPENROWSET, pay-per-query model ideal for infrequent access. Data Factory requires ETL and target database costs. Databricks requires cluster costs even with auto-termination. Serverless SQL provides SQL interface without data movement or idle costs.

Front:
A web application deployed across 3 Azure regions must remain operational with automatic failover if 1 region fails. Maximum tolerable downtime: 5 minutes. Maximum data loss: 1 minute of transactions.

A) Azure SQL Database with active geo-replication and auto-failover group
B) Azure Cosmos DB with multi-region writes
C) Azure SQL Database with geo-restore from backups
Back: A) Azure SQL Database with active geo-replication and auto-failover group
Extra: Auto-failover groups provide automatic failover within minutes, RPO ~1 minute with continuous replication. Multi-region writes (Cosmos) are over-engineered if app doesn't need write scaling. Geo-restore from backup takes hours (fails RTO). Auto-failover meets both RTO (5 min) and RPO (1 min) requirements.

Front:
Your company's ERP applications run on Azure VMs across 2 regions. Disaster recovery requirements: RPO 4 hours, RTO 6 hours. The solution must minimize infrastructure costs when not in disaster recovery mode.

A) Azure Site Recovery with replication to secondary region
B) Maintain warm standby VMs in secondary region with load balancer
C) Daily VM snapshots copied to secondary region storage
Back: A) Azure Site Recovery with replication to secondary region
Extra: ASR provides continuous replication (sub-hour RPO possible), orchestrated failover, and no standby VM costs (VMs only created during failover). Warm standby doubles costs. Daily snapshots can't meet 4-hour RPO and manual failover may exceed RTO. ASR is cost-effective DR purpose-built for VMs.

Front:
A mission-critical SQL database requires 99.99% uptime SLA, automatic failover within 1 minute, and zero data loss during planned maintenance or region failure.

A) Azure SQL Managed Instance Business Critical with auto-failover group
B) Azure SQL Database General Purpose with geo-replication
C) Azure SQL Database Business Critical with zone redundancy
Back: C) Azure SQL Database Business Critical with zone redundancy
Extra: Business Critical + zone redundancy provides 99.995% SLA (exceeds requirement), synchronous replication across zones (zero data loss), automatic failover in seconds. Auto-failover groups are for region failures with async replication (potential data loss). General Purpose can't meet zero data loss for maintenance.

Front:
Your organization needs to back up 500 Azure VMs with file-level restore capability, 35-day retention, and compliance requirement for immutable backups preventing deletion even by admins.

A) Azure Backup with soft delete and immutability enabled
B) Azure Backup with geo-redundant Recovery Services Vault
C) Managed disk snapshots with lifecycle management
Back: A) Azure Backup with soft delete and immutability enabled
Extra: Azure Backup supports VM backups, file-level restore, immutability for compliance (prevents admin deletion), and flexible retention. GRS provides redundancy but not immutability. Disk snapshots lack centralized management, file-level restore, and immutability features. Azure Backup is purpose-built for this scenario.

Front:
An application stores data in Azure SQL Database. Business requirements: 15-minute point-in-time restore for the last 7 days, long-term backup retention for 10 years (yearly backups).

A) Azure SQL Database automated backups with long-term retention policy
B) Export database to Blob Storage with lifecycle management
C) Use SQL Database geo-replication for backup
Back: A) Azure SQL Database automated backups with long-term retention policy
Extra: SQL Database automated backups provide PITR (5-35 days configurable), long-term retention (LTR) supports up to 10 years with weekly/monthly/yearly backups. Export to Blob is manual and doesn't provide PITR. Geo-replication is for availability, not backups. LTR is purpose-built for compliance retention.

Front:
A stateful application runs on Azure VMs with data stored on managed disks. The application must be protected against zonal failures with automatic failover and minimal configuration changes.

A) Deploy VMs in Availability Zones with zone-redundant storage
B) Use VM scale sets with load balancer across zones
C) Deploy VMs in Availability Set
Back: A) Deploy VMs in Availability Zones with zone-redundant storage
Extra: Availability Zones provide physical separation (datacenter isolation), ZRS replicates disks synchronously across zones. VM in one zone fails, data available in another. Scale sets require stateless design. Availability Sets protect against rack failures within a datacenter, not zonal failures. Zones provide highest resilience.

Front:
A containerized application must achieve 99.95% availability with automatic scaling and distribution across fault domains to survive datacenter-level failures within a region.

A) Azure Kubernetes Service with system node pool across Availability Zones
B) Azure Container Instances with restart policy
C) Azure App Service with multiple instances
Back: A) Azure Kubernetes Service with system node pool across Availability Zones
Extra: AKS across AZs provides zone redundancy, automatic pod rescheduling, and horizontal scaling. ACI doesn't support multi-zone or orchestration. App Service can span zones but containers on AKS offer better orchestration. AKS + AZ is the resilient container orchestration solution meeting 99.95% SLA.

Front:
Your company needs to replicate on-premises Hyper-V VMs to Azure for disaster recovery with orchestrated failover/failback and network mapping. RPO requirement: 5 minutes. RTO: 2 hours.

A) Azure Site Recovery with Hyper-V replication
B) Hyper-V Replica to Azure VMs
C) Azure Backup for Hyper-V VMs
Back: A) Azure Site Recovery with Hyper-V replication
Extra: ASR supports Hyper-V replication with 5-minute RPO (configurable), orchestrated failover/failback, network mapping, and recovery plans. Hyper-V Replica to Azure requires manual setup. Azure Backup provides backups but not replication or orchestrated DR. ASR is the comprehensive DR solution for Hyper-V to Azure.

Front:
A web application uses Azure Cosmos DB. Business continuity requirements: survive complete region failure with automatic failover, maximum 1-hour data loss acceptable, 99.99% read availability during regional outage.

A) Cosmos DB with multi-region writes and automatic failover
B) Cosmos DB with single-region write and read regions with automatic failover
C) Cosmos DB with manual failover to secondary region
Back: B) Cosmos DB with single-region write and read regions with automatic failover
Extra: Single write region with read replicas provides automatic read failover (99.99% reads maintained), RPO ~1 hour acceptable with continuous replication. Multi-region writes add complexity/cost if not needed. Manual failover violates automatic requirement. This configuration balances cost, availability, and meets stated RPO.

Front:
An application processes large files uploaded by users. Files must be backed up within 1 hour of upload with 90-day retention and protection against ransomware delete operations.

A) Azure Backup for Azure Files with soft delete and immutable vault
B) Azure Files with share snapshots and RBAC
C) Copy files to Blob Storage Archive tier
Back: A) Azure Backup for Azure Files with soft delete and immutable vault
Extra: Azure Backup for Files provides scheduled backups (<1 hour possible), 90-day retention, soft delete (recover from attacks), and immutable vaults prevent deletion even by admins. Snapshots are point-in-time but not protected from admin deletion. Archive tier is for long-term storage, not active backups.

Front:
Your application tier VMs must be distributed to minimize impact from planned maintenance, with no more than 20% of VMs unavailable during updates. Current deployment: 10 VMs in a single region.

A) Deploy VMs in a VM scale set with update domains
B) Deploy VMs across multiple Availability Zones
C) Deploy VMs in an Availability Set with 5 update domains
Back: C) Deploy VMs in an Availability Set with 5 update domains
Extra: Availability Set with 5 update domains ensures max 20% (2/10 VMs) down during planned maintenance. Scale sets are for scaling, not necessary here. Availability Zones provide zonal redundancy but overkill if requirement is only maintenance windows. Update domains are designed specifically for planned maintenance impact.

Front:
A database must support point-in-time restore for the last 35 days with ability to restore to any second within that window, and long-term yearly backups for 7 years for compliance.

A) Azure SQL Database with 35-day PITR and LTR policy
B) Azure SQL Managed Instance with automated backups
C) Custom backup using BACPAC exports to Blob Storage
Back: A) Azure SQL Database with 35-day PITR and LTR policy
Extra: SQL Database supports configurable PITR (7-35 days) with per-second granularity, LTR for yearly backups up to 10 years. Managed Instance has same features but more expensive without specific need. BACPAC exports are manual, lack PITR granularity, and require restoration logic. SQL Database built-in features are optimal.

Front:
An application deployed across multiple Azure regions must route users to the closest healthy region with automatic failover if a region becomes unavailable. Health checks must detect application-level failures.

A) Azure Front Door with health probe-based routing
B) Azure Traffic Manager with priority routing
C) Azure Load Balancer with availability zones
Back: A) Azure Front Door with health probe-based routing
Extra: Front Door provides global load balancing, latency-based routing (closest region), application-level health probes, and automatic failover. Traffic Manager Priority is manual ordering. Load Balancer is regional, not global. Front Door combines CDN, global load balancing, and SSL offload with intelligent health detection.

Front:
Your SaaS application data must survive simultaneous failure of an entire Azure region and specific datacenter within the surviving region. The solution must be cost-optimized.

A) Geo-zone-redundant storage (GZRS)
B) Geo-redundant storage (GRS) with LRS
C) Zone-redundant storage (ZRS) in multiple regions
Back: A) Geo-zone-redundant storage (GZRS)
Extra: GZRS combines ZRS (3 zones in primary) with GRS (async replication to secondary region), protecting against zone and region failure with single SKU. Option B doesn't protect against zone failure in primary. Option C requires manual replication management. GZRS provides both protections cost-effectively.

Front:
A legacy application runs on a single VM requiring 99.9% uptime. The application is stateless behind a load balancer. Minimize infrastructure cost while meeting SLA.

A) Single VM with Premium SSD and Azure Backup
B) Two VMs in Availability Set with Standard Load Balancer
C) VM scale set with 2 instances across Availability Zones
Back: B) Two VMs in Availability Set with Standard Load Balancer
Extra: Single VM SLA is 95-99.5% (can't meet 99.9%). Availability Set with 2+ VMs provides 99.95% SLA, lower cost than zones. Scale sets add complexity for static count. Two VMs in Availability Set is the minimum configuration meeting 99.9%+ SLA cost-effectively for stateless apps.

Front:
An e-commerce application must automatically recover from regional Azure datacenter failures within 5 minutes with zero data loss. The application uses SQL Database and App Service.

A) App Service with multi-region deployment, SQL Database Business Critical with zone redundancy
B) Azure Front Door, App Service in secondary region, SQL Database with auto-failover group
C) Traffic Manager, App Service in Availability Zones, SQL Database geo-replication
Back: A) App Service with multi-region deployment, SQL Database Business Critical with zone redundancy
Extra: Zone redundancy handles datacenter (not region) failures within 5 min with zero data loss via synchronous replication across zones in same region. Auto-failover groups are for region failures with async replication (potential data loss). The question asks for datacenter failure - zones are the answer, not regions.

Front:
Your company requires daily backups of 200 Azure VMs with 30-day retention and ability to restore individual files without restoring entire VMs. Backup data must be stored in a different region.

A) Azure Backup with geo-redundant Recovery Services Vault and instant restore
B) Managed disk snapshots copied to secondary region
C) Custom script with VM export to Blob Storage GRS
Back: A) Azure Backup with geo-redundant Recovery Services Vault and instant restore
Extra: Azure Backup provides centralized VM backup, file-level restore via instant restore, GRS vault for regional redundancy, and managed retention. Disk snapshots require manual orchestration and lack file-level restore. Custom scripts lack enterprise features. Azure Backup is purpose-built for this requirement.

Front:
A Cosmos DB application must maintain write availability during complete region failure with automated failover and no application code changes. Reads can tolerate brief inconsistency during failover.

A) Multi-region write with Eventual consistency
B) Single write region with automatic failover policy
C) Manual failover with Strong consistency
Back: B) Single write region with automatic failover policy
Extra: Automatic failover policy promotes a read region to write region automatically when primary fails (no code changes). Eventual consistency acceptable during failover. Multi-region write is expensive if not needed. Manual failover contradicts automatic requirement. Single write + auto-failover balances availability and cost.

Front:
Your application requires backup of Azure File shares with snapshots taken every 4 hours, 90-day retention, and centralized backup management with compliance reporting.

A) Azure Backup for Azure Files with custom policy
B) Azure Files share snapshots with scheduled script
C) Copy files to Blob Storage with lifecycle management
Back: A) Azure Backup for Azure Files with custom policy
Extra: Azure Backup for Files supports custom schedules (multi-snapshot per day), retention policies, centralized management, and compliance reporting. Share snapshots require manual scheduling and lack centralized management. Blob copy creates data duplication without backup-specific features. Azure Backup provides enterprise backup management.

Front:
An application must run compute workloads based on API requests with sub-second cold start times, automatic scaling from 0 to 1000 instances, and per-request billing. No server management required.

A) Azure Functions with Premium plan
B) Azure Container Instances with Azure Functions
C) Azure Kubernetes Service with KEDA autoscaling
Back: A) Azure Functions with Premium plan
Extra: Functions Premium provides sub-second cold starts (pre-warmed instances), automatic scaling 0-1000+, per-execution billing, and serverless. ACI doesn't scale like Functions. AKS requires cluster management. Functions Premium eliminates cold start issues of Consumption plan while maintaining serverless benefits.

Front:
Your company needs to run a legacy .NET Framework application requiring specific Windows registry settings and COM components. The application must run in Azure with minimal refactoring.

A) Azure Virtual Machines running Windows Server
B) Azure App Service with Windows containers
C) Azure Container Instances with Windows containers
Back: A) Azure Virtual Machines running Windows Server
Extra: Legacy apps with registry/COM dependencies typically require full OS control - VMs provide this. App Service containers have limitations on registry/COM. ACI is for stateless workloads. While containerization is ideal long-term, VMs offer the lift-and-shift path with minimal refactoring for complex legacy dependencies.

Front:
A data processing job runs nightly for 4 hours, processing 10TB of data with 100 parallel workers. The job is fault-tolerant and can restart failed tasks. Minimize costs.

A) Azure Batch with low-priority VMs
B) Azure Kubernetes Service with standard nodes
C) Azure Virtual Machine Scale Sets with Spot VMs
Back: A) Azure Batch with low-priority VMs
Extra: Azure Batch is purpose-built for parallel batch processing with job scheduling, task management, and autoscaling. Low-priority VMs offer 80% discount, acceptable for fault-tolerant workloads. AKS adds orchestration complexity not needed. VMSS Spot works but lacks Batch's job management features. Batch + low-priority optimizes cost for batch workloads.

Front:
A microservices application requires orchestration with service discovery, automatic scaling, rolling updates, and secret management. The team has Kubernetes expertise and needs cloud-agnostic portability.

A) Azure Kubernetes Service (AKS) with Azure Key Vault integration
B) Azure Container Apps with Dapr
C) Azure App Service with deployment slots
Back: A) Azure Kubernetes Service (AKS) with Azure Key Vault integration
Extra: AKS provides full Kubernetes with service discovery, HPA/VPA scaling, rolling updates, and portability. Team expertise aligns. Key Vault integration for secrets. Container Apps is simpler but less portable. App Service isn't container-native orchestration. AKS matches requirements including cloud-agnostic portability goal.

Front:
An event-driven application must process messages from a queue with automatic scaling based on queue depth (0-100 instances). The processing code is packaged as a container image requiring persistent storage.

A) Azure Container Apps with KEDA scaling and Azure Files mount
B) Azure Functions with container support
C) Azure Kubernetes Service with custom autoscaler
Back: A) Azure Container Apps with KEDA scaling and Azure Files mount
Extra: Container Apps provides KEDA-based queue scaling, container support, volume mounts (Azure Files), and serverless pricing (0 instances when idle). Functions containers have limitations on persistent storage. AKS requires more management. Container Apps is optimized for event-driven containers with built-in scaling.

Front:
A web API must autoscale based on custom metrics (database connection count) with sub-minute scaling response time and support for blue-green deployments.

A) Azure App Service with Application Insights autoscale rules
B) Azure Kubernetes Service with custom metrics adapter
C) Azure VM Scale Sets with custom metric autoscale
Back: B) Azure Kubernetes Service with custom metrics adapter
Extra: AKS with custom metrics adapter (Prometheus/Azure Monitor) supports any metric, sub-minute HPA scaling, and native blue-green via services/deployments. App Service autoscale has limited custom metrics. VMSS has slower scaling (<1 min difficult). AKS provides the flexibility for custom metrics and deployment strategies.

Front:
Your organization needs to deploy 500 identical VMs for a rendering farm that processes jobs from a queue. VMs must scale automatically based on queue length and tolerate individual VM failures.

A) Azure Virtual Machine Scale Sets with autoscale rules
B) Azure Batch with auto-pool feature
C) Individual VMs with Azure Automation for provisioning
Back: A) Azure Virtual Machine Scale Sets with autoscale rules
Extra: VMSS provides automated scaling based on metrics, identical VM deployment, fault tolerance with availability sets/zones. Batch is for job scheduling (possible but VMSS more direct). Individual VMs don't scale automatically. VMSS is purpose-built for identical VM fleets with autoscaling and self-healing.

Front:
A stateful application requires 16TB RAM and 128 vCPUs for in-memory data processing. The workload runs continuously. Minimize costs while meeting requirements.

A) Azure HBv3-series VM optimized for memory-intensive workloads
B) Multiple Standard VMs with distributed processing
C) Azure M-series memory-optimized VM with Reserved Instance
Back: C) Azure M-series memory-optimized VM with Reserved Instance
Extra: M-series offers up to 24TB RAM and 128 vCPUs for in-memory workloads. Reserved Instances (1-3 year) provide up to 72% discount for continuous workloads. HBv3 is for HPC, not in-memory apps. Multiple VMs add complexity for stateful apps. M-series + RI optimizes cost for continuous high-memory requirements.

Front:
A containerized application must scale from 10 to 1000 instances in under 10 seconds based on HTTP request rate. The solution must minimize idle costs and not require Kubernetes expertise.

A) Azure Container Apps with HTTP scaling
B) Azure Kubernetes Service with cluster autoscaler
C) Azure App Service with Docker container support
Back: A) Azure Container Apps with HTTP scaling
Extra: Container Apps provides built-in HTTP request scaling with KEDA, rapid scaling (seconds), and serverless pricing (scale to zero). AKS cluster autoscaler takes minutes for node provisioning. App Service containers have slower scaling. Container Apps purpose-built for rapid elastic scaling without K8s complexity.

Front:
An application requires serverless compute with VNET integration for access to on-premises resources via ExpressRoute and must run for up to 30 minutes per execution.

A) Azure Functions Premium plan with VNET integration
B) Azure Functions Consumption plan with VNET
C) Azure Container Apps with VNET integration
Back: A) Azure Functions Premium plan with VNET integration
Extra: Functions Premium supports VNET integration, no timeout limits (vs 10 min in Consumption), and ExpressRoute access. Consumption plan can't do VNET integration. Container Apps work but Functions align better with serverless execution model. Premium plan provides VNET + long execution + serverless.

Front:
Your company must run GPU-accelerated machine learning training jobs with datasets stored in Azure Blob Storage. Jobs run daily for 8 hours. Cost optimization is critical.

A) Azure Machine Learning with GPU compute clusters and autoscaling
B) Azure Virtual Machines with Spot instances and automatic shutdown
C) Azure Kubernetes Service with GPU node pools
Back: A) Azure Machine Learning with GPU compute clusters and autoscaling
Extra: Azure ML provides managed compute clusters with autoscaling (scale to 0), native Blob integration, job scheduling, and experiment tracking. VMs require manual management. AKS adds K8s complexity. Azure ML is purpose-built for ML workloads with cost controls (cluster auto-shutdown, low-priority nodes).

Front:
A web application requires asynchronous processing of uploaded images. Processing takes 2-5 minutes per image with 1000 images/hour average. The solution must scale automatically and minimize costs during off-peaks.

A) Azure Functions Consumption plan triggered by Blob Storage
B) Azure Logic Apps with Blob Storage trigger
C) Azure Container Apps with Storage Queue scaling
Back: A) Azure Functions Consumption plan triggered by Blob Storage
Extra: Functions Consumption provides automatic scaling, pay-per-execution (cost-effective for variable load), and native Blob trigger. Logic Apps have higher per-execution cost. Container Apps work but add complexity for simple async processing. Functions Consumption optimal for event-driven variable workloads.

Front:
Your company needs to migrate 100 VMs from VMware on-premises to Azure with minimal downtime and ability to rollback if issues occur post-migration.

A) Azure Migrate with Azure Site Recovery for replication and test failover
B) Convert VMs to VHDs and upload to Azure Storage
C) Azure Database Migration Service
Back: A) Azure Migrate with Azure Site Recovery for replication and test failover
Extra: Azure Migrate provides assessment, ASR replicates VMs with minimal downtime, test failover validates migration, and rollback capabilities. Manual VHD conversion has downtime and no rollback. DMS is for databases not VMs. Azure Migrate + ASR is the comprehensive VM migration solution with test/rollback.

Front:
An application handles file uploads that trigger processing pipelines. Processing must be guaranteed once-per-message even if consumers crash. Message retention: 14 days for troubleshooting.

A) Azure Service Bus queue with PeekLock and dead-letter queue
B) Azure Storage Queue with visibility timeout
C) Azure Event Grid with retry policy
Back: A) Azure Service Bus queue with PeekLock and dead-letter queue
Extra: Service Bus provides at-least-once delivery with PeekLock (prevents message loss on consumer crash), dead-letter for poison messages, and up to 14-day retention. Storage Queue has 7-day max retention. Event Grid is for reactive events, not reliable queue processing. Service Bus is enterprise messaging for guaranteed delivery.

Front:
A microservices architecture requires a service to publish domain events (OrderCreated, PaymentProcessed) to multiple subscribers without the publisher knowing about subscribers. Events must be delivered to all current and future subscribers.

A) Azure Event Grid with custom topics and event subscriptions
B) Azure Service Bus topic with subscriptions
C) Azure Event Hubs with multiple consumer groups
Back: A) Azure Event Grid with custom topics and event subscriptions
Extra: Event Grid is purpose-built for pub/sub event distribution with loose coupling. Publishers don't know subscribers. New subscriptions receive future events. Service Bus topics work but Event Grid is optimized for discrete events. Event Hubs is for streaming. Event Grid provides filtering, retry, and webhook delivery.

Front:
An IoT solution ingests 100,000 events/second from devices, requires 7-day replay capability for reprocessing, and multiple independent consumers must process events at different speeds.

A) Azure Event Hubs with multiple consumer groups and 7-day retention
B) Azure Service Bus queue with sessions
C) Azure Event Grid with storage queue subscriptions
Back: A) Azure Event Hubs with multiple consumer groups and 7-day retention
Extra: Event Hubs is designed for high-throughput streaming with replay (retention up to 90 days), independent consumer groups (each tracks own offset), and partition scale. Service Bus caps at lower throughput. Event Grid doesn't support replay. Event Hubs is the streaming platform for this scenario.

Front:
A web API experiences traffic spikes with repeated requests for the same data within 5-minute windows. The solution must reduce database load and provide sub-millisecond response times for cached data.

A) Azure Cache for Redis with sliding expiration
B) Azure CDN with cache rules
C) Application-level in-memory caching
Back: A) Azure Cache for Redis with sliding expiration
Extra: Redis provides sub-ms latency, distributed cache (shared across app instances), sliding expiration (resets on access), and scales independently. CDN is for static content. In-memory cache isn't shared across instances. Redis is the distributed cache solution for dynamic API responses with low latency.

Front:
Your application requires externalized configuration with dynamic updates without application restart, feature flags for gradual rollouts, and access control for configuration management.

A) Azure App Configuration with feature management and Key Vault references
B) Azure Key Vault for all configuration
C) Configuration files in Azure Blob Storage
Back: A) Azure App Configuration with feature management and Key Vault references
Extra: App Configuration is purpose-built for config management with dynamic refresh, feature flags, label-based environments, and Key Vault references for secrets. Key Vault is for secrets not app config. Blob Storage lacks structured config features. App Configuration provides versioning, change tracking, and RBAC.

Front:
A mobile backend API requires routing to different backend versions (v1, v2) based on client app version, rate limiting per client, and response caching with CDN.

A) Azure API Management with version-based routing and policies
B) Azure Front Door with routing rules
C) Azure Application Gateway with path-based routing
Back: A) Azure API Management with version-based routing and policies
Extra: APIM provides API versioning, rate limiting policies, response caching, and backend routing logic. Front Door is global load balancing without API-specific features. App Gateway is L7 load balancing without API management. APIM is the API gateway for versioning, policies, dev portal, and transformation.

Front:
Your deployment pipeline must deploy application updates to Azure App Service with zero downtime, automatic rollback on failure detection, and gradual traffic shifting from old to new version.

A) Azure App Service deployment slots with traffic routing and auto-swap
B) Azure Front Door with backend pool weighting
C) Blue-green deployment with Traffic Manager
Back: A) Azure App Service deployment slots with traffic routing and auto-swap
Extra: Deployment slots provide slot swapping (instant zero-downtime), traffic routing (% split for canary), and auto-swap with health checks for rollback. Front Door requires manual backend management. Traffic Manager DNS-based (not instant). Slots are native App Service feature designed for continuous deployment patterns.

Front:
A global e-commerce site requires minimal latency for users worldwide, SSL termination at the edge, DDoS protection, and automatic failover between multiple regional backends.

A) Azure Front Door with WAF and health probes
B) Azure Application Gateway with zone redundancy
C) Azure Traffic Manager with priority routing
Back: A) Azure Front Door with WAF and health probes
Extra: Front Door is global CDN/load balancer with edge SSL termination, WAF (DDoS protection), health-based routing, and automatic failover. App Gateway is regional only. Traffic Manager is DNS-based (slower failover, no SSL termination). Front Door provides comprehensive global application delivery.

Front:
An application tier in Azure requires load balancing across 10 VMs within a single region with support for TCP/UDP protocols, source IP affinity, and health monitoring.

A) Azure Standard Load Balancer with health probes
B) Azure Application Gateway with backend pools
C) Azure Traffic Manager with performance routing
Back: A) Azure Standard Load Balancer with health probes
Extra: Standard Load Balancer provides L4 (TCP/UDP) load balancing, source IP affinity (session persistence), health probes, zone redundancy, and regional scope. App Gateway is L7 (HTTP/HTTPS only). Traffic Manager is DNS-based global. Standard LB is the regional L4 load balancing solution with high throughput.

Front:
A multi-tier application requires internal load balancing between web and application tiers within a VNet without exposing application tier to the internet.

A) Azure Internal Load Balancer with private IP
B) Azure Application Gateway with internal mode
C) Azure Front Door with private link
Back: A) Azure Internal Load Balancer with private IP
Extra: Internal Load Balancer provides private IP load balancing within VNet, no internet exposure, and L4 support. App Gateway internal works for HTTP but adds cost for simple load balancing. Front Door is internet-facing. Internal LB is purpose-built for private VNet load balancing between tiers.

Front:
Your company needs dedicated private connectivity from on-premises datacenter (1Gbps) to Azure with consistent latency, not traversing the public internet, and 99.95% availability SLA.

A) Azure ExpressRoute with two circuits for redundancy
B) Site-to-Site VPN with BGP routing
C) Point-to-Site VPN with Azure AD authentication
Back: A) Azure ExpressRoute with two circuits for redundancy
Extra: ExpressRoute provides dedicated private connection (50Mbps-100Gbps), predictable latency, doesn't traverse internet, and dual circuits provide 99.95% SLA. VPN traverses internet with variable latency. P2S is for individual users. ExpressRoute is the enterprise private connectivity solution with SLA guarantees.

Front:
A branch office network (50 users) requires secure connectivity to Azure VNets with automatic routing and ability to access multiple VNets without complex routing configuration.

A) Site-to-Site VPN with Virtual WAN hub
B) ExpressRoute with Global Reach
C) Point-to-Site VPN with client certificates
Back: A) Site-to-Site VPN with Virtual WAN hub
Extra: Virtual WAN provides hub-and-spoke with automatic routing to multiple VNets, S2S VPN for branch connectivity, and simplified management. ExpressRoute is expensive for branches. P2S is for individual users not branch office. Virtual WAN simplifies multi-site, multi-VNet connectivity with automatic routing.

Front:
An application requires direct internet outbound connectivity from VMs with inspection and filtering of traffic based on URLs and fully qualified domain names (FQDNs).

A) Azure Firewall with application rules
B) Network Security Groups with service tags
C) NAT Gateway with route table
Back: A) Azure Firewall with application rules
Extra: Azure Firewall supports FQDN filtering in application rules (L7), threat intelligence, and centralized management. NSGs operate at L4 (IP/port) and don't support FQDN filtering. NAT Gateway provides outbound internet without filtering. Azure Firewall provides the enterprise security with FQDN-based policies.

Front:
Multiple Azure VNets across different regions must communicate privately with centralized security inspection and routing control. The solution must support transitive routing between all VNets.

A) Azure Virtual WAN with secured hub (Azure Firewall)
B) VNet peering with user-defined routes
C) Azure Firewall in hub VNet with peering
Back: A) Azure Virtual WAN with secured hub (Azure Firewall)
Extra: Virtual WAN provides any-to-any connectivity with hub-and-spoke, integrated Azure Firewall for security, and automatic transitive routing. VNet peering requires manual non-transitive routing. Hub-spoke with manual peering works but lacks VWAN automation. VWAN is the modern solution for global network mesh with security.

Front:
A web application tier must allow inbound HTTPS traffic from the internet but deny all other inbound traffic and restrict outbound traffic to only Azure SQL Database and Azure Storage.

A) Network Security Group with inbound/outbound rules and service tags
B) Azure Firewall with DNAT rules
C) Application Security Groups only
Back: A) Network Security Group with inbound/outbound rules and service tags
Extra: NSG provides stateful subnet/NIC security with allow/deny rules, service tags for Azure services (SQL, Storage), and priority-based processing. Azure Firewall is centralized (overkill for single subnet). ASGs group VMs but don't provide rules alone. NSG is the native security for subnet-level traffic filtering.

Front:
Your application requires name resolution between VMs across multiple VNets and integration with on-premises DNS via conditional forwarding.

A) Azure Private DNS zones with VNet links and DNS forwarder VM
B) Azure DNS public zones with VNet integration
C) Custom DNS server on VMs in each VNet
Back: A) Azure Private DNS zones with VNet links and DNS forwarder VM
Extra: Private DNS zones provide VNet name resolution with automatic registration, link to multiple VNets, and DNS forwarder VM enables conditional forwarding to on-premises. Public DNS is internet-facing. Custom DNS per VNet doesn't scale. Private DNS + forwarder provides hybrid DNS integration.

Front:
A multi-tier application requires network isolation between tiers (web, app, data) with the ability to apply security rules based on application roles rather than IP addresses.

A) Application Security Groups with NSG rules referencing ASGs
B) Separate VNets for each tier with peering
C) Network Security Groups with IP-based rules
Back: A) Application Security Groups with NSG rules referencing ASGs
Extra: ASGs group VMs by application role, NSG rules reference ASGs instead of IPs (simplifies management as VMs change). Separate VNets add complexity. IP-based NSGs don't scale with dynamic environments. ASGs provide logical grouping for security policies based on application context.

Front:
An application deployed in Azure requires low-latency access to a SaaS application (Microsoft 365) with consistent performance and traffic not traversing the public internet backbone.

A) Azure ExpressRoute with Microsoft peering
B) Site-to-Site VPN with forced tunneling
C) Direct internet connectivity with Azure Front Door
Back: A) Azure ExpressRoute with Microsoft peering
Extra: ExpressRoute Microsoft peering provides private connection to Microsoft 365, bypasses public internet, and offers consistent latency. VPN goes through internet. Direct internet has variable performance. ExpressRoute is the solution for optimized connectivity to Microsoft cloud services (365, Dynamics).

Front:
Your company needs to monitor network traffic between virtual machines in Azure with packet-level capture for security analysis and troubleshooting.

A) Network Watcher packet capture and NSG flow logs
B) Azure Monitor with VM insights
C) Azure Firewall logs
Back: A) Network Watcher packet capture and NSG flow logs
Extra: Network Watcher provides packet capture (pcap files for analysis) and NSG flow logs for traffic patterns. VM insights provides performance metrics not network packets. Firewall logs are centralized but don't capture all VM-to-VM traffic. Network Watcher is the network diagnostics tool for packet-level visibility.

Front:
A hub VNet hosts shared services (DNS, firewall). 20 spoke VNets connect to the hub. Spoke VNets must access the internet through the hub firewall but not communicate with each other directly.

A) Hub-spoke topology with UDR routing traffic to Azure Firewall, no spoke-to-spoke peering
B) Full mesh VNet peering with NSGs
C) Virtual WAN with routing intent
Back: A) Hub-spoke topology with UDR routing traffic to Azure Firewall, no spoke-to-spoke peering
Extra: Hub-spoke with UDR forces traffic through hub firewall, peer spokes to hub only (blocks lateral spoke traffic), firewall controls access. Mesh peering defeats isolation goal. Virtual WAN enables any-to-any by default (opposite of requirement). Hub-spoke with controlled routing provides isolation + centralized egress.

Front:
An application requires SSL/TLS termination at the load balancer, URL path-based routing to different backend pools, and Web Application Firewall protection.

A) Azure Application Gateway with WAF SKU
B) Azure Load Balancer with SSL offload
C) Azure Front Door Standard
Back: A) Azure Application Gateway with WAF SKU
Extra: Application Gateway provides L7 features: SSL termination, path-based routing, WAF protection, and backend reencryption. Load Balancer is L4 only (no path routing or WAF). Front Door works but App Gateway is regional solution for this scenario. App Gateway + WAF provides web security with advanced routing.

Front:
Your company must implement DNS resolution for private Azure services (Storage, SQL) accessible via Private Link from on-premises and multiple Azure VNets.

A) Azure Private DNS zones with VNet links and Private Endpoint DNS integration
B) Public DNS with CNAME records
C) On-premises DNS with custom A records
Back: A) Azure Private DNS zones with VNet links and Private Endpoint DNS integration
Extra: Private DNS zones automatically create A records for Private Endpoints, VNet links enable resolution from Azure, DNS forwarder enables on-premises resolution. Public DNS resolves to public IPs (defeats Private Link). Custom records don't maintain automatically. Private DNS is the integrated solution for Private Link name resolution.

Front:
Your organization uses Azure AD for identity management. External consultants need temporary access to Azure Portal and specific resource groups for 2-week engagements with MFA enforcement.

A) Azure AD B2B guest accounts with Conditional Access and PIM
B) Create temporary Azure AD accounts with time-based policies
C) Share credentials with Azure AD Identity Protection
Back: A) Azure AD B2B guest accounts with Conditional Access and PIM
Extra: B2B guest accounts bring external users into tenant securely, Conditional Access enforces MFA, PIM provides time-bound access with automatic expiration. Temporary AD accounts violate governance. Credential sharing is a security violation. B2B is designed for secure external collaboration with governance controls.

Front:
An application must authenticate users from multiple Azure AD tenants (multi-tenant SaaS) and authorize access based on user roles defined in each customer's tenant.

A) Azure AD multi-tenant app registration with Conditional Access
B) Azure AD B2C with custom user flows
C) Separate app registration per customer tenant
Back: A) Azure AD multi-tenant app registration with Conditional Access
Extra: Multi-tenant app registration allows users from any Azure AD tenant to sign in, app receives tenant-specific tokens, roles come from user's home tenant. B2C is for customer identities not B2B multi-tenancy. Separate registrations don't scale. Multi-tenant registration is the SaaS identity pattern.

Front:
Your company requires that all Azure resources created in production subscriptions must have an Owner tag and cannot be deployed to certain regions (e.g., non-compliant data residency regions).

A) Azure Policy with Deny effect for regions and Append effect for tags
B) Azure Blueprints with resource locks
C) RBAC custom role limiting deployment regions
Back: A) Azure Policy with Deny effect for regions and Append effect for tags
Extra: Policy with Deny prevents deployment to disallowed regions, Append adds missing tags automatically. Blueprints are for initial setup. RBAC controls who can deploy, not where. Policy provides continuous compliance enforcement for both geography restrictions and tagging requirements across all resources.

Front:
You need to track and alert on changes to Azure RBAC assignments across 100 subscriptions, with alerts sent to a Security Operations team within 5 minutes of changes.

A) Azure Activity Log with Log Analytics and alert rules
B) Azure Policy compliance reports
C) Azure Advisor recommendations
Back: A) Azure Activity Log with Log Analytics and alert rules
Extra: Activity Log captures RBAC changes (authorization writes), stream to Log Analytics, create alert rules with action groups for near-real-time notification. Policy tracks compliance not RBAC changes. Advisor is for recommendations not real-time monitoring. Activity Log + Log Analytics provides comprehensive RBAC audit trail.

Front:
An application requires access to Azure Key Vault secrets during CI/CD pipeline execution in GitHub Actions. The solution must not store long-lived credentials in GitHub.

A) Configure OpenID Connect with Azure AD workload identity federation
B) Store service principal credentials in GitHub Secrets
C) Use Azure Key Vault task with certificate authentication
Back: A) Configure OpenID Connect with Azure AD workload identity federation
Extra: Workload identity federation allows GitHub Actions to get Azure AD tokens without credentials using OIDC trust. No secrets stored in GitHub. Option B stores credentials (security risk). Option C still requires certificate management. OIDC federation eliminates credential storage for GitHub Actions to Azure authentication.

Front:
Your organization has 500 Azure subscriptions. You need to visualize the management group hierarchy, view policy assignments at each level, and identify subscriptions out of compliance.

A) Azure Resource Graph queries with Kusto visualizations
B) Azure Policy compliance dashboard
C) Azure Cost Management hierarchy view
Back: A) Azure Resource Graph queries with Kusto visualizations
Extra: Resource Graph can query management group structure, policy assignments, and compliance state across all subscriptions with KQL. Policy dashboard shows compliance but not hierarchy. Cost Management is for billing not governance. Resource Graph provides queryable governance data across the entire tenant.

Front:
A database contains sensitive customer data (PII) that must be encrypted at rest with customer-managed keys, with key rotation every 90 days and audit logs of all key access.

A) Azure SQL Database with TDE using customer-managed key in Key Vault
B) Azure SQL Database with service-managed TDE
C) Application-level encryption before database storage
Back: A) Azure SQL Database with TDE using customer-managed key in Key Vault
Extra: TDE with customer-managed key (CMK) in Key Vault provides encryption at rest with customer control, Key Vault audit logs track access, supports rotation. Service-managed TDE uses Microsoft keys (no customer control). Application encryption adds complexity. TDE with CMK balances security with manageability.

Front:
An IoT solution processes telemetry from 1 million devices. Devices send data every 5 seconds. Data must be processed in near real-time for anomaly detection and stored for historical analysis.

A) Event Hubs for ingestion, Stream Analytics for processing, Cosmos DB for storage
B) Service Bus for ingestion, Azure Functions for processing, SQL Database for storage
C) Event Grid for ingestion, Logic Apps for processing, Blob Storage for storage
Back: A) Event Hubs for ingestion, Stream Analytics for processing, Cosmos DB for storage
Extra: Event Hubs handles high-throughput ingestion (1M devices × 12 events/min), Stream Analytics provides real-time CEP, Cosmos DB scales for high-velocity writes. Service Bus doesn't scale to this ingestion rate. Event Grid is for discrete events not continuous telemetry. This is the IoT reference architecture.

Front:
A financial application requires that all database queries are audited with log retention for 7 years, protected from tampering, and accessible for compliance reviews.

A) Azure SQL Database auditing to Log Analytics with immutable storage export
B) Enable SQL Database diagnostic settings to Storage Account
C) Configure database change tracking and version history
Back: A) Azure SQL Database auditing to Log Analytics with immutable storage export
Extra: SQL auditing logs all queries, Log Analytics for analysis, export to immutable Blob storage for tamper-proof 7-year retention. Diagnostic settings don't capture queries. Change tracking is for data changes not auditing. SQL auditing + immutable storage meets compliance and tamper-proof requirements.

Front:
Your data warehouse queries 50TB of data with unpredictable query patterns (some queries daily, others monthly). The solution must minimize costs while maintaining query performance.

A) Azure Synapse serverless SQL pool with Data Lake Storage
B) Azure Synapse dedicated SQL pool with auto-pause
C) Azure SQL Database Hyperscale with read replicas
Back: A) Azure Synapse serverless SQL pool with Data Lake Storage
Extra: Serverless SQL pool charges per query (TB scanned), no idle costs, perfect for unpredictable patterns. Dedicated pool has provisioned costs even when paused. Hyperscale is for OLTP not analytics. Serverless + Data Lake provides pay-per-query economics for variable workload data warehouse scenarios.

Front:
An application stores user-generated content (videos, images) totaling 500TB with 10TB monthly growth. Access pattern: 90% of accesses are to content uploaded in the last 7 days.

A) Blob Storage Hot tier with lifecycle policy to Cool after 7 days, Archive after 90 days
B) Blob Storage Cool tier for all data
C) Azure Files Premium with snapshots
Back: A) Blob Storage Hot tier with lifecycle policy to Cool after 7 days, Archive after 90 days
Extra: Hot tier optimizes for frequent access (7 days), automatic transition to Cool tier reduces storage costs for older content, Archive for long-term retention. Cool tier for all data increases access costs. Premium Files is expensive for this scale. Lifecycle management automates tier optimization.

Front:
A machine learning team needs to store and version 10TB of training datasets with POSIX filesystem access, Git-like versioning for experiments, and integration with Azure ML.

A) Azure Data Lake Storage Gen2 with hierarchical namespace
B) Azure Blob Storage with blob versioning
C) Azure Files with file share snapshots
Back: A) Azure Data Lake Storage Gen2 with hierarchical namespace
Extra: ADLS Gen2 provides POSIX semantics (required for ML frameworks), hierarchical namespace for organization, integrates with Azure ML, supports access control. Blob versioning isn't Git-like versioning. Azure Files lacks analytics optimizations. ADLS Gen2 is purpose-built for analytical/ML workloads.

Front:
Your application requires a distributed cache shared across 50 app instances with sub-millisecond latency, support for complex data structures (sorted sets, geospatial), and 99.9% availability.

A) Azure Cache for Redis Premium tier with clustering
B) Azure Cosmos DB with low latency reads
C) Azure SQL Database with in-memory tables
Back: A) Azure Cache for Redis Premium tier with clustering
Extra: Redis Premium provides sub-ms latency, clustering for scale, 99.9% SLA, complex data structures (sorted sets, geo indexes), and distributed cache capability. Cosmos DB has higher latency. SQL in-memory isn't a distributed cache solution. Redis is purpose-built for caching with advanced data structures.

Front:
A reporting solution must query data from Azure SQL Database, Cosmos DB, and on-premises Oracle without data movement and present unified results via T-SQL queries.

A) Azure Synapse Analytics with PolyBase and Linked Server
B) Azure Data Factory with data flows
C) Power BI with DirectQuery to each source
Back: A) Azure Synapse Analytics with PolyBase and Linked Server
Extra: Synapse PolyBase queries external data sources (SQL, Oracle, Cosmos) without movement, unified T-SQL interface, supports JOINs across sources. Data Factory moves data (ETL). Power BI is for visualization not query layer. Synapse provides distributed query engine for heterogeneous sources.

Front:
Your organization must ensure RPO of 15 minutes and RTO of 1 hour for mission-critical VMs running stateful applications across Azure regions.

A) Azure Site Recovery with replication to secondary region
B) Backup to Recovery Services Vault with restore testing
C) VM snapshots replicated to secondary region
Back: A) Azure Site Recovery with replication to secondary region
Extra: ASR provides continuous replication (sub-hour RPO achievable), orchestrated failover meeting 1-hour RTO, application-consistent snapshots. Backup typically has longer RTO (restore time). Snapshots require manual orchestration. ASR is purpose-built for meeting aggressive RPO/RTO requirements with minimal management.

Front:
A SQL database must support automatic failover to secondary region during outages, with stale read tolerance of up to 5 seconds for reporting queries and zero-downtime planned maintenance.

A) Azure SQL Database Business Critical with auto-failover group and read replica
B) Azure SQL Database General Purpose with active geo-replication
C) Azure SQL Managed Instance with manual failover
Back: A) Azure SQL Database Business Critical with auto-failover group and read replica
