Extra: Business Critical provides zone redundancy (zero-downtime maintenance), auto-failover groups for region failover, geo-replicas for read scale with ~5 second lag. General Purpose doesn't support zero-downtime maintenance. Manual failover contradicts automatic requirement. Business Critical + auto-failover meets all requirements.

Front:
Your Kubernetes cluster must survive zone failures with automatic pod rescheduling, persistent volume availability, and no single point of failure for control plane.

A) Azure Kubernetes Service with system node pool across Availability Zones and ZRS disks
B) AKS with single zone and regular backup
C) AKS with Availability Set and standard disks
Back: A) Azure Kubernetes Service with system node pool across Availability Zones and ZRS disks
Extra: AKS across zones provides control plane redundancy, automatic pod rescheduling to healthy zones, ZRS persistent volumes available across zones. Single zone creates SPOF. Availability Sets don't protect against datacenter failures. Multi-zone AKS with ZRS storage provides comprehensive zone resiliency.

Front:
An on-premises application using SQL Server must be migrated to Azure with minimal downtime (under 10 minutes), maintaining compatibility with existing client connections using Windows authentication.

A) Azure SQL Managed Instance with online migration using Database Migration Service
B) Azure SQL Database with offline migration and connection string changes
C) SQL Server on Azure VMs with backup/restore
Back: A) Azure SQL Managed Instance with online migration using Database Migration Service
Extra: SQL MI supports Windows authentication (Azure AD DS integration), near-online migration via DMS (<10 min cutover), maintains SQL Server compatibility (linked servers, CLR). SQL Database requires auth changes. VM migration has longer downtime. SQL MI is the migration path for enterprise SQL Server features.

Front:
A stateless web application must automatically scale from 5 to 100 instances based on CPU and HTTP queue length with scale-out/in decisions completed in under 30 seconds.

A) Azure App Service with autoscale rules for CPU and HTTP queue
B) Azure VM Scale Sets with custom script extension
C) Azure Kubernetes Service with HPA
Back: A) Azure App Service with autoscale rules for CPU and HTTP queue
Extra: App Service autoscale supports multiple metrics (CPU, HTTP queue), sub-30 second response for PaaS scaling, managed platform. VMSS has slower scale operations (VM provisioning). AKS HPA is fast but adds K8s complexity. App Service provides the fastest PaaS scaling for web workloads with built-in HTTP queue metric.

Front:
A batch processing job requires 1000 cores for 2 hours nightly. The job is fault-tolerant and can handle interruptions. Minimize costs.

A) Azure Batch with Spot VMs and automatic retry
B) Azure Kubernetes Service with spot node pools
C) Azure VM Scale Sets with on-demand instances
Back: A) Azure Batch with Spot VMs and automatic retry
Extra: Batch manages job scheduling with automatic task retry on preemption, Spot VMs offer up to 90% discount for interruptible workload. AKS adds orchestration overhead. On-demand VMSS doesn't leverage discounted compute. Batch + Spot optimizes cost for fault-tolerant batch processing with built-in retry logic.

Front:
Your application requires orchestration of long-running workflows (hours to days) with human approval steps, retries, and state persistence across workflow steps.

A) Azure Durable Functions with activity functions and human interaction pattern
B) Azure Logic Apps with approval connectors
C) Azure Data Factory pipeline with web activity
Back: A) Azure Durable Functions with activity functions and human interaction pattern
Extra: Durable Functions supports long-running stateful workflows, human interaction pattern for approvals, automatic state persistence, and retry policies. Logic Apps work but Durable Functions offers more control and code-first approach. Data Factory is for data pipelines not general workflows. Durable Functions is the serverless workflow engine.

Front:
A containerized microservices application requires service mesh capabilities (traffic management, observability, security) without changing application code.

A) Azure Kubernetes Service with Open Service Mesh or Istio add-on
B) Azure Container Apps with Dapr
C) Azure App Service with Application Gateway
Back: A) Azure Kubernetes Service with Open Service Mesh or Istio add-on
Extra: AKS supports service mesh add-ons (OSM, Istio) providing traffic splitting, mTLS, observability without code changes. Dapr is microservices building blocks not full mesh. App Service isn't service mesh. Service mesh on AKS provides advanced networking and security for microservices at infrastructure level.

Front:
Your organization needs to migrate 200 physical servers to Azure. Assessment shows 80% can be modernized to PaaS, 20% require IaaS. The solution must provide discovery, dependency mapping, and cost estimation.

A) Azure Migrate with assessment and modernization tools
B) Manual server inventory with Azure Pricing Calculator
C) Azure Site Recovery for replication
Back: A) Azure Migrate with assessment and modernization tools
Extra: Azure Migrate provides agentless discovery, dependency mapping, performance-based sizing, PaaS readiness assessment (App Service, SQL), and cost estimation. Manual inventory doesn't scale. ASR is for replication not assessment. Azure Migrate is the comprehensive migration planning and execution platform.

Front:
A web API requires protection against SQL injection, XSS, and DDoS attacks with automatic threat intelligence updates and custom rule support.

A) Azure Application Gateway with WAF v2 and OWASP ruleset
B) Azure Front Door with WAF and custom rules
C) Network Security Groups with default rules
Back: A) Azure Application Gateway with WAF v2 and OWASP ruleset
Extra: App Gateway WAF v2 provides OWASP protection (SQL injection, XSS), DDoS protection, custom rules, and regional deployment. Front Door offers global scale (may be overkill). NSGs are L4 only, no application attack protection. App Gateway WAF is the regional web application firewall for OWASP threats.

Front:
An application in Azure needs to communicate with Azure Storage over Microsoft's private network without traversing the internet, while keeping storage account publicly inaccessible.

A) Azure Private Link with Private Endpoint for Storage Account
B) Service Endpoints for Storage Account
C) VPN Gateway with forced tunneling
Back: A) Azure Private Link with Private Endpoint for Storage Account
Extra: Private Endpoint places storage in VNet with private IP,DisablePublicNetworkAccess blocks internet, traffic stays on Microsoft backbone. Service Endpoints still allow public IP access (less secure). VPN is for hybrid connectivity. Private Link provides the highest security with full network isolation.

Front:
Your multi-region application requires global routing based on client geography, automatic failover on health check failures, and support for both Azure and on-premises endpoints.

A) Azure Traffic Manager with geographic routing and health probes
B) Azure Front Door with latency-based routing
C) Azure Load Balancer with zone redundancy
Back: A) Azure Traffic Manager with geographic routing and health probes
Extra: Traffic Manager provides DNS-based global routing with geographic profiles, health monitoring, supports Azure + on-premises endpoints. Front Door requires HTTP/HTTPS (not all protocols). Load Balancer is regional. Traffic Manager is the multi-protocol global traffic director for hybrid scenarios.

Front:
A VNet must allow inbound SSH only from specific on-premises IP ranges, allow outbound HTTPS to any destination, and log all denied traffic for security analysis.

A) Network Security Group with priority-based rules and NSG Flow Logs
B) Azure Firewall with application rules
C) Route table with forced tunneling
Back: A) Network Security Group with priority-based rules and NSG Flow Logs
Extra: NSG provides IP/port-based filtering with priority rules, NSG Flow Logs capture denied traffic for analysis. Firewall is overkill for simple IP filtering. Route tables control routing not filtering. NSG + Flow Logs provides security filtering with logging for forensics at subnet/NIC level.

Front:
Your company requires centralized logging from Azure resources, on-premises servers, and application logs with 2-year retention and ability to query across sources using KQL.

A) Log Analytics workspace with Azure Monitor agent and data retention policy
B) Azure Storage Account with lifecycle management
C) Event Hubs with Stream Analytics
Back: A) Log Analytics workspace with Azure Monitor agent and data retention policy
Extra: Log Analytics centralizes logs from Azure, hybrid, and apps via agents, supports KQL queries across sources, configurable retention (up to 2 years + Archive). Storage lacks query capability. Event Hubs is streaming not log storage. Log Analytics is the unified log aggregation and query platform.

Front:
An application must emit custom business metrics (orders processed, revenue) to Azure Monitor for dashboard visualization and alert rules based on metric thresholds.

A) Application Insights with custom metrics and metric alerts
B) Send logs to Log Analytics and create log-based alerts
C) Store metrics in Cosmos DB with custom alerting
Back: A) Application Insights with custom metrics and metric alerts
Extra: Application Insights TrackMetric() emits custom metrics, metric alerts provide near-real-time threshold monitoring, native dashboard integration. Log-based alerts have higher lag. Custom Cosmos solution lacks platform integration. Application Insights is the APM platform for custom application telemetry and alerting.

Front:
Your infrastructure team needs to query resource configurations across 1000 subscriptions to identify VMs without backup configured and export results to CSV.

A) Azure Resource Graph with KQL query and export
B) PowerShell script iterating through subscriptions
C) Azure Policy compliance reports
Back: A) Azure Resource Graph with KQL query and export
Extra: Resource Graph queries all subscriptions simultaneously with KQL (scale + speed), supports JOIN operations (VMs with backup status), export to CSV. PowerShell iteration slow at scale. Policy reports compliance not ad-hoc queries. Resource Graph is the fast multi-subscription resource query service.

Front:
A mission-critical application requires monitoring with automatic alerting when availability drops below 99.9% over 5-minute windows and automatic incident creation in ServiceNow.

A) Azure Monitor availability tests with action groups and ITSM connector
B) Application Insights with custom queries
C) Azure Advisor recommendations
Back: A) Azure Monitor availability tests with action groups and ITSM connector
Extra: Availability tests (URL ping, multi-step) measure uptime, alert rules trigger on availability metrics, ITSM connector creates ServiceNow incidents automatically. Custom queries don't provide uptime monitoring. Advisor is for optimization not real-time monitoring. Monitor availability tests + ITSM is the SLA monitoring solution.

Front:
Your application architecture consists of 20 microservices deployed across AKS, App Services, and Functions. You need distributed tracing to track requests across services with correlation IDs.

A) Application Insights with distributed tracing and correlation
B) Azure Monitor Logs with custom queries
C) Event Hub with correlation headers
Back: A) Application Insights with distributed tracing and correlation
Extra: Application Insights provides distributed tracing with automatic correlation across services, application map visualization, end-to-end transaction tracking. Monitor Logs require manual correlation. Event Hub is for events not tracing. Application Insights is the distributed tracing platform with native multi-service support.

Front:
A data pipeline processes sensitive data. You must ensure all pipeline activities are logged with data lineage tracking and compliance reports showing data flow from source to destination.

A) Azure Data Factory with monitoring and lineage in Purview
B) Azure Synapse with audit logs only
C) Custom logging to Blob Storage
Back: A) Azure Data Factory with monitoring and lineage in Purview
Extra: Data Factory logs all activities, integrates with Purview for data lineage (source to sink visibility), compliance reporting. Synapse audit logs lack lineage visualization. Custom logging doesn't provide governance features. Data Factory + Purview provides enterprise data governance with visual lineage tracking.

Front:
Your company requires cost allocation across 50 business units sharing Azure subscriptions. Each resource must be tagged with business unit and cost center, with monthly cost reports by tag.

A) Azure Cost Management with tag-based cost analysis and budgets
B) Export billing data to Blob Storage and custom Power BI
C) Azure Advisor cost recommendations
Back: A) Azure Cost Management with tag-based cost analysis and budgets
Extra: Cost Management filters by tags for cost allocation, creates budgets per tag, automated reports. Custom exports require ongoing maintenance. Advisor provides recommendations not cost allocation. Cost Management is the native platform for tag-based cost tracking and chargeback reporting.

Front:
An application requires secret rotation every 30 days with zero downtime. During rotation, both old and new secrets must be valid for 24-hour overlap to allow gradual rollout.

A) Azure Key Vault with versioning and application configured for version rotation
B) Store secrets in Azure App Configuration
C) Environment variables with manual updates
Back: A) Azure Key Vault with versioning and application configured for version rotation
Extra: Key Vault stores secret versions, application reads latest + previous version during rotation window, supports automatic rotation via integrations. App Configuration is for settings not secrets. Environment variables require app restart. Key Vault versioning enables zero-downtime rotation with overlap period.

Front:
Your application is deployed in 3 regions. Users must be routed to the closest region based on latency with automatic failover to next-closest region if health checks fail.

A) Azure Front Door with latency-based routing and health probes
B) Azure Traffic Manager with performance routing
C) Azure Load Balancer with zone redundancy
Back: A) Azure Front Door with latency-based routing and health probes
Extra: Front Door uses anycast for latency-based routing (closest PoP), health probes detect failures, automatic failover to healthy backends, SSL at edge. Traffic Manager is DNS-based (slower cutover). Load Balancer is regional. Front Door provides global low-latency routing with fast failover for web workloads.

Front:
A containerized application must scale to zero instances when idle to minimize costs, but support rapid scale-out (0 to 50 instances in 10 seconds) when messages arrive in a queue.

A) Azure Container Apps with KEDA queue scaling
B) Azure Kubernetes Service with HPA
C) Azure Functions with container support
Back: A) Azure Container Apps with KEDA queue scaling
Extra: Container Apps with KEDA scales to zero (no cost when idle), queue-based scaling triggers rapid scale-out, supports custom containers. AKS doesn't scale to zero without virtual nodes. Functions containers have limitations. Container Apps provides serverless container scaling with KEDA event sources.

Front:
Your organization requires immutable infrastructure deployments where infrastructure changes are deployed as new resources rather than updating existing ones, with automated rollback on failure.

A) Azure Deployment Manager with blue-green deployment steps
B) ARM templates with incremental mode
C) Azure DevOps pipelines with manual approval
Back: A) Azure Deployment Manager with blue-green deployment steps
Extra: Deployment Manager orchestrates blue-green deployments (new parallel infrastructure), health checks determine promotion, automatic rollback on failure. Incremental ARM updates existing resources. Manual approvals don't provide automatic rollback. Deployment Manager enables immutable infrastructure patterns with safety checks.

Front:
An application requires caching with support for pub/sub messaging between application instances, geospatial queries, and automatic failover across availability zones.

A) Azure Cache for Redis Premium with zone redundancy and geo-replication
B) Azure Cosmos DB with multi-region writes
C) Azure SignalR Service
Back: A) Azure Cache for Redis Premium with zone redundancy and geo-replication
Extra: Redis Premium supports pub/sub, geospatial commands, zone redundancy for HA, optional geo-replication. Cosmos DB doesn't provide pub/sub or geospatial via cache interface. SignalR is for real-time messaging not cache. Redis Premium is the feature-rich cache with advanced data structures and HA.

Front:
Your company deploys applications using GitOps. The solution must continuously reconcile desired state in Git with actual cluster state and automatically apply changes when Git is updated.

A) Azure Kubernetes Service with Flux or ArgoCD GitOps operator
B) Azure DevOps pipeline with kubectl apply
C) ARM templates with CI/CD pipeline
Back: A) Azure Kubernetes Service with Flux or ArgoCD GitOps operator
Extra: GitOps operators (Flux, Argo) continuously watch Git repos, automatically sync cluster state, provide declarative reconciliation. DevOps pipelines are imperative (not continuous reconciliation). ARM is for Azure resources not K8s. Flux/Argo on AKS provides true GitOps with continuous drift correction.

Front:
A user must access Azure resources with elevated privileges only when needed. Access requests require manager approval and must be logged with automatic expiration after 4 hours.

A) Azure AD Privileged Identity Management with approval workflow
B) Just-in-time VM access with Azure Security Center
C) Azure AD groups with dynamic membership
Back: A) Azure AD Privileged Identity Management with approval workflow
Extra: PIM provides just-in-time role activation with approval workflows, time-bound assignments (4 hours), and comprehensive audit logs. JIT VM access is for VM port opening not RBAC. Dynamic groups are membership-based not time-bound access. PIM is designed for privileged access governance with approval and auditing.

Front:
Your organization has separate Azure AD tenants for subsidiaries that must remain independent. Users need single sign-on across all tenants without account synchronization.

A) Azure AD B2B cross-tenant access settings with automatic redemption
B) Azure AD federation with ADFS
C) Merge all tenants into single directory
Back: A) Azure AD B2B cross-tenant access settings with automatic redemption
Extra: Cross-tenant access settings allow B2B collaboration between tenants while maintaining independence, automatic redemption provides seamless SSO, no synchronization needed. ADFS adds complexity. Merging tenants violates independence requirement. Cross-tenant settings enable multi-tenant collaboration without directory consolidation.

Front:
An application must verify the identity of Azure resources it communicates with to prevent token theft and man-in-the-middle attacks in a zero-trust architecture.

A) Managed identities with service-to-service authentication via Azure AD
B) Shared access signatures with IP restrictions
C) API keys with Azure Key Vault storage
Back: A) Managed identities with service-to-service authentication via Azure AD
Extra: Managed identities provide Azure AD authentication between services with token validation, eliminating password-based auth and supporting zero-trust principles. SAS tokens are bearer tokens (theft risk). API keys don't verify service identity. Managed identity with Azure AD provides mutual authentication for zero-trust.

Front:
Your company requires centralized identity governance showing all users with privileged access, their assignments, and last review date with automatic access expiration if not recertified quarterly.

A) Azure AD Access Reviews with automated decisions
B) Azure AD PIM with time-bound assignments
C) Manual spreadsheet with RBAC queries
Back: A) Azure AD Access Reviews with automated decisions
Extra: Access Reviews provide scheduled recertification campaigns with automatic removal on non-approval, supports PIM roles and group memberships, audit trail. PIM is for activation not recertification. Manual process doesn't scale. Access Reviews automate the quarterly access recertification lifecycle for governance.

Front:
An application deployed across multiple clouds (Azure, AWS, GCP) requires unified identity management with users authenticating once and accessing resources in all clouds.

A) Azure AD with SAML/OIDC federation to AWS and GCP
B) Separate identity systems per cloud
C) On-premises Active Directory with VPN
Back: A) Azure AD with SAML/OIDC federation to AWS and GCP
Extra: Azure AD acts as central IdP, federates to AWS (IAM SAML) and GCP (Workspace/Cloud Identity OIDC), single sign-on across clouds. Separate systems fragment identity. On-prem AD requires connectivity and lacks cloud-native features. Azure AD provides multi-cloud identity hub with SSO and Conditional Access.

Front:
Your organization must enforce MFA for all users accessing production environments but allow password-only authentication for development environments accessed from corporate network.

A) Azure AD Conditional Access with location and environment-based policies
B) Azure AD security defaults
C) Per-user MFA settings in Azure AD
Back: A) Azure AD Conditional Access with location and environment-based policies
Extra: Conditional Access creates context-aware policies (location, resource, group membership), granular control per environment. Security defaults enforce MFA globally (no exceptions). Per-user MFA doesn't consider context. Conditional Access provides the risk-based adaptive authentication for differentiated environments.

Front:
A database contains customer records with credit card numbers. Regulatory requirements mandate that DBAs can administer the database but cannot view sensitive columns.

A) Azure SQL Database Dynamic Data Masking for sensitive columns
B) Always Encrypted with column encryption
C) Row-level security with DBA exclusion
Back: A) Azure SQL Database Dynamic Data Masking for sensitive columns
Extra: Dynamic Data Masking hides sensitive columns from non-privileged users (DBAs) while allowing administration, configurable masking rules. Always Encrypted requires client-side key access (impacts querying). RLS controls rows not columns. DDM provides column-level obfuscation for privileged user scenarios meeting compliance.

Front:
An analytics platform processes 100TB of raw JSON log files. Queries filter by date range and user ID. The solution must minimize query costs and support schema evolution.

A) Azure Data Lake Storage Gen2 with partitioned folders (date/user) and Synapse serverless SQL
B) Azure Cosmos DB with composite indexes
C) Azure SQL Database with JSON columns
Back: A) Azure Data Lake Storage Gen2 with partitioned folders (date/user) and Synapse serverless SQL
Extra: ADLS Gen2 with folder partitioning enables partition elimination (reduced data scanned = lower cost), serverless SQL pay-per-query, flexible schema. Cosmos DB expensive for 100TB. SQL Database not optimized for massive JSON analytics. ADLS + serverless SQL optimizes cost with partition pruning and schema flexibility.

Front:
Your application stores session state with requirements: sub-5ms read/write latency, automatic expiration after 20 minutes of inactivity, and session data shared across 100 application instances.

A) Azure Cache for Redis with sliding expiration
B) Azure Cosmos DB with TTL
C) In-memory cache per application instance
Back: A) Azure Cache for Redis with sliding expiration
Extra: Redis delivers sub-5ms latency, sliding expiration resets on access (idle timeout), distributed cache shared across instances. Cosmos DB has higher latency. In-memory cache isn't shared across instances. Redis is purpose-built for session state with ASP.NET Core provider and sliding expiration support.

Front:
A multi-tenant SaaS database solution requires data isolation per tenant with ability to move large tenants to dedicated databases while maintaining application code compatibility.

A) Azure SQL Database elastic pools with tenant-per-schema or tenant-per-database
B) Single database with tenant ID filter in all queries
C) Cosmos DB with partition key per tenant
Back: A) Azure SQL Database elastic pools with tenant-per-schema or tenant-per-database
Extra: Elastic pools share resources across tenant databases, supports hybrid model (small tenants share, large tenants isolated), maintains T-SQL compatibility. Single-database risks data leakage and doesn't scale. Cosmos DB partitioning has limits. SQL elastic pools provide flexible multi-tenancy with resource sharing and isolation.

Front:
Your data pipeline ingests streaming data from IoT devices with deduplication required within 5-minute tumbling windows before writing to storage.

A) Azure Stream Analytics with DISTINCT and tumbling window
B) Azure Event Hubs with consumer group deduplication
C) Azure Functions with manual deduplication logic
Back: A) Azure Stream Analytics with DISTINCT and tumbling window
Extra: Stream Analytics provides windowing functions (tumbling), DISTINCT for deduplication, SQL-like syntax, and managed scaling. Event Hubs doesn't deduplicate. Functions require custom logic and state management. Stream Analytics is the serverless stream processing engine with built-in windowing and deduplication.

Front:
A time-series database must store sensor data with support for downsampling (reducing resolution over time) and automatic data aggregation for historical queries.

A) Azure Data Explorer with update policy for aggregation and retention policy
B) Azure Cosmos DB with TTL
C) Azure SQL Database with temporal tables
Back: A) Azure Data Explorer with update policy for aggregation and retention policy
Extra: ADX update policies pre-aggregate data on ingestion, retention policies auto-delete old raw data, optimized for time-series queries and analytics. Cosmos DB lacks time-series optimizations. SQL temporal tables track history not time-series aggregation. ADX is purpose-built for time-series with ingestion-time aggregation.

Front:
An application requires full-text search across product catalog (5 million items) with autocomplete, faceted navigation, and geo-filtering with <100ms query latency.

A) Azure Cognitive Search with suggester, facets, and geo-spatial search
B) Cosmos DB with custom search implementation
C) Azure SQL Database full-text search
Back: A) Azure Cognitive Search with suggester, facets, and geo-spatial search
Extra: Cognitive Search provides suggester (autocomplete), faceted navigation, geo-spatial queries, relevance tuning, and <100ms performance at scale. Cosmos DB doesn't have built-in full-text. SQL full-text lacks geo-spatial richness. Cognitive Search is purpose-built for complex search scenarios with low latency.

Front:
Your organization must store 1PB of compliance documents with versioning, legal hold preventing deletion during litigation, and audit trail of all access.

A) Azure Blob Storage with versioning, immutability policy (legal hold), and diagnostic logs
B) Azure Files with snapshots and RBAC
C) Azure Data Lake with ACLs
Back: A) Azure Blob Storage with versioning, immutability policy (legal hold), and diagnostic logs
Extra: Blob versioning maintains document history, immutability legal hold prevents deletion/modification even by admins, diagnostic logs track all access. Files/Data Lake lack immutability. Blob immutability provides SEC 17a-4 compliance for long-term archival with legal hold and audit capabilities.

Front:
A database migration from on-premises Oracle to Azure requires minimal downtime with continuous replication during migration and ability to rollback if issues occur.

A) Azure Database Migration Service with online migration mode
B) Export/import with downtime window
C) Third-party replication tools
Back: A) Azure Database Migration Service with online migration mode
Extra: DMS online mode provides continuous replication (CDC), minimal downtime cutover, pre-migration assessment and can maintain source until validated. Export/import requires extended downtime. Third-party adds complexity. DMS is Microsoft's managed migration service with online replication for Oracle to Azure SQL/PostgreSQL.

Front:
An application stores frequently accessed hot data (10GB) and large archival data (10TB). Hot data needs <10ms access, archival accessed once quarterly. Minimize costs while meeting performance requirements.

A) Azure Cache for Redis for hot data, Blob Storage Archive tier for archival
B) Cosmos DB for all data with different consistency levels
C) Premium SSD managed disks for all data
